metadata.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Company Limited v. Respondents (Congress Mazdoor Sangh Workers)

facts.text: Appellant owns six collieries, concerned with Sijua and Bhelatand collieries.
Due to power shortage from heavy percolation of water overloading power-house, appellant decided to stagger weekly rest days.

Notice dated September 10, 1963 introduced new schedule: Sijua every Wednesday rest day, Bhelatand every Friday (later changed to Thursday) rest day, effective from September 15, 1963 (Sunday). Previously Sunday was rest day in all collieries.
Workers did not turn up for work on September 15, 1963.

Negotiations held between appellant and workmen represented by Colliery Mazdoor Sangh; agreed new schedule from September 22, 1963. Respondents (Congress Mazdoor Sangh members) not party to agreement.
Workers did not turn up on September 22, 1963.
Appellant filed two applications under para 8(1) of Coal Mines Bonus Scheme before Regional Labour Commissioner (Central), Dhanbad, declaring illegal strike on September 22, 1963.
Workmen went to Sijua Colliery on September 25, 1963 (Wednesday); appellant refused work as weekly rest day.
Workmen went to Bhelatand Colliery on September 26, 1963 (Thursday); appellant refused work as weekly rest day.
Shri B. N. Sharma (President, Congress Mazdoor Sangh) filed applications before Regional Labour Commissioner declaring illegal lock-out on September 25 (Sijua) and September 26 (Bhelatand).
Regional Labour Commissioner order dated November 22, 1963: non-working on September 25 (Sijua) and 26 (Bhelatand) due to illegal lock-out for purposes of Scheme.
Appellant filed four more applications for strikes on September 15 and 29, 1963; withdrew September 15 applications post-agreement.
Regional Labour Commissioner order dated November 14, 1964: no strike, much less illegal strike, on September 22 and 29, 1963, as change in rest days not in accordance with law.
Appellant appealed to Central Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad; appeals dismissed.
Appellant filed six writ petitions in Patna High Court; disposed by two judgments dated November 16, 1966, upholding lower decisions and dismissing writs.
Six appeals to Supreme Court on certificate from Patna High Court.
General Notice September 27, 1963 by Chief Mining Inspector restoring old schedule as power house defects attended.

legal_issues.text: Whether change in weekly rest days from Sunday to other days (Wednesday/Thursday) required notice under Section 9A of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as it affects matters in Fourth Schedule (items 4,5,8).
Whether para 8 of Coal Mines Bonus Scheme is ultra vires, creating quasi-judicial tribunal without legislative authority.
Whether there were illegal strikes by workers on September 22 and 29, 1963, depriving bonus.
Whether there were illegal lock-outs on September 25 (Sijua) and 26 (Bhelatand), 1963.

petitioner_arguments.text: Change in rest days not a change in conditions of service under Fourth Schedule items 4 (rest intervals during working hours), 5 (leave/holidays), or 8 (customary concession/usage).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 9A Industrial Disputes Act; Fourth Schedule items 4,5,8

petitioner_arguments.text: Emergency power shortage unforeseen, short-lived; impossible to give 21 days notice; no financial loss to workers.
Para 8 of Scheme ultra vires as creates quasi-judicial tribunal by executive, beyond Section 5 Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 5 and Third Schedule, Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act, 1948

respondent_arguments.text: Change falls under Fourth Schedule item 8 (change in usage/customary concession of Sunday rest), item 4 (rest intervals including weekly), item 5 (holidays with wages).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 9A Industrial Disputes Act; Fourth Schedule items 4,5,8

respondent_arguments.text: Emergency visualized for six weeks in notice; could have laid off workers with pay to avoid overload.
Para 8 intra vires under item 7 Third Schedule as necessary for implementing Scheme (dispute resolution on bonus).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 5 and Third Schedule item 7, Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act, 1948

court_reasoning.text: Para 8 of Scheme valid as subordinate legislation on ancillary details within guidelines of Section 5 and Third Schedule item 7; not excessive delegation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delegation permissible if policy laid down; para 8 provides procedure for disputes on strikes under Scheme.

court_reasoning.text: Change in weekly rest days requires notice u/s 9A as falls under Fourth Schedule items 4 (hours of work and rest intervals), 5 (holidays), 8 (change in usage/customary privilege); Sunday rest has significance beyond finance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of s.9A is consultation; liberal construction needed.

court_reasoning.text: No notice given, so change ineffective; old Sunday schedule operative; no illegal strike on Sep 22/29.
Refusal to work on Sep 25/26 deliberate closure knowing dispute; coal public utility service, no s.22 notice, so illegal lock-out u/s 24.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere refusal not lock-out, but context makes it so.

holdings.text: Para 8 of Coal Mines Bonus Scheme intra vires.
Change in weekly rest days without s.9A notice ineffective.
No illegal strike by workers on September 22 and 29, 1963.
Illegal lock-outs by appellant on September 25 (Sijua) and 26 (Bhelatand), 1963.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice required for change in rest days; illegal lock-out without notice in public utility service.

statutes_cited.name: Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers framing of Bonus Scheme including matters necessary for implementation like dispute resolution.

statutes_cited.name: Coal Mines Bonus Scheme
statutes_cited.relevance: Declaration of illegal strike/lock-out affecting bonus; procedure valid.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Recognizes importance of Sunday rest days.

outcome.summary: All six appeals dismissed upholding Patna High Court, Regional Labour Commissioner, and Central Industrial Tribunal decisions that there were no illegal strikes by workers but illegal lock-outs by appellant, entitling workers to bonus.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; status quo on lower court orders favouring respondents.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. Only one set of costs.

key_quotes.text: The real object and purpose of enacting S. 9A seems to be to afford an opportunity to the workmen to consider the effect of the proposed change and, if necessary, to represent their point of view on the proposal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of s.9A notice requirement.

key_quotes.text: Whether the paid day of rest is a Sunday or some other week day would no doubt cause no financial loss to the workmen. But the financial benefit cannot be the sole criterion.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies why change in rest day requires notice despite no wage loss.

key_quotes.text: Para 8 of the Scheme is accordingly valid and it cannot be considered to amount to excessive delegation of legislative power.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds validity of Scheme's dispute resolution mechanism.
